strengths.title: Django
strengths.content:
I was recently tasked with making a website for my school newspaper. This led to me learning and becoming very familiar with the ins and outs of Django. I found the framework very intuitive and finished the website.
The website is now live at https://talktown.org. Unfortunately, I am not allowed to share any login details for the website as it would violate a child protection policy that my school enforces. I will include some screen shots of the website when a user is logged in below:

strengths.title: React JS
strengths.content:
When working on web projects, I found that some of my ideas were too simple for a large server side rendering framework like Django, so I learnt Javascript to work on React projects. An example of my React would be my StudentsMarket project, a yet-to-launch marketplace for students in my school to sell and buy books by listing their books online.
Link to Github

strengths.title: Python
strengths.content: My first programming language that I ever learnt was Python around 5 years ago (When I was around 11). Since then, I have worked on countless projects, many of which were small learning experiences. Only recently have I been able to use my skills for real world projects.

strengths.title: Next JS
strengths.content: After learning React, I seeked a solution for a Search Engine friendly framework for my portfolio. I quickly found Next Js and learnt it for this website.

strengths.title: HTML & CSS
strengths.content: HTML and CSS was my first exposure into the web-dev community. I now consider myself proficient in transferring designs into HTML and CSS. I have also been able to take advantage of TailwindCSS and Bootstrap in my projects.

strengths.title: AWS
strengths.content: When I was working on my backend for the school newspaper, I quickly found that I needed a robust hosting, DNS and database services. With a combination of Amazon Route 53, LightSail, RDS and many headaches, I made a fully functioning backend for my project and have learnt a lot of the nuances when working with Amazon Web Services.
